Award.AwardTitle: Economic Models for Collaborative Access Network Provisioning: US-Finland Collaboration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Increased capacity in wireless networks has largely come from shrinking cell sizes, but continuing this trend has become impractical for large operators. Small wireless networks are also straining in overcrowded spectrum bands. The problems are particularly acute in high-density 802.11 deployments. It is clear that a collaborative approach, taking advantage of both large infrastructure deployment by operators and distributed deployments of 802.11 and femtocell networks could be extremely beneficial. This project focuses on three major problems related to heterogeneous wireless networks. First, models are developed that quantify the gains from cooperation between large operators and small-scale operators and end users deploying their own wireless access networks. Second, game theoretic and pricing models are developed to study incentive structures to support collaboration in heterogeneous wireless networks. Third, a threat model is developed to specifically model security threats that would impact a heterogeneous wireless network through a holistic vulnerability assessment. These three tasks are all complemented by frequent prototyping and experimentation.

This work will be immediately applicable to real networks and will quantify the benefits of collaboration for network operators. In addition, the collaborative project will deepen technological collaboration between the United States and Finland. The models developed in this project will all be available and published in the scientific literature, providing a holistic understanding of heterogeneous wireless networks. These models will catalyze the further technical development of protocols and standards to support open, heterogeneous wireless networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increased capacity in wireless networks has largely come from shrinking cell sizes, but continuing this trend has become impractical for large operators. Small wireless networks are also straining in overcrowded spectrum bands. The problems are particularly acute in high-density 802.11 deployments. It is clear that a collaborative approach, taking advantage of both large infrastructure deployment by operators and distributed deployments of 802.11 and femtocell networks could be extremely beneficial. This project focused on three major problems related to heterogeneous wireless networks. The project was pursued in collaboration with researchers from the University of Oulu, Finland. The participation of the Finnish researchers was supported by Tekes, a funding agency in Finland.

The first goal of the project was to develop models to understand how much could be gained through cooperation between large cellular operators and small WLAN (WiFi) operators. In support of this goal, we developed mathematical models to understand the capacity of multihop, multioperator, multitechnology (M3) networks, and we described these models in a journal article, which is still under review. We also developed a new network architecture, which we termed the Dynamic Network Architecture (DNA) in which the role that nodes play in the network might change over time, depending upon the needs of the network and the capabilities of the node. For instance, a node might make a better relay node in a network if it was connected to power, and it might be a good choice to act as a temporary access point if it were connected to a wired network connection. This architecture was described and analyzed in a paper that has been accepted to IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking.

The second major goal of the project was to develop game theoretic and pricing models to study incentive structures that support collaboration in the kinds of heterogeneous wireless networks that we envision. Here, the project developed two different models. One model considered adding WLAN access points for offloading in multihop cellular networks (M3), finding that the performance of the network could be dramatically increased with only a few WLAN access points and that these gains were extremely robust to the geographic distribution of the new access points. A second model considered adding WLAN offloading to single-hop cellular networks, like the cellular networks in use today. This model was used to analyze what happens when multiple cellular operators compete to use WLAN offloading resources. The model showed, among other things, that the use of offloading would be highly dependent on the cost structures of the cellular networks themselves. These results were published in two conference papers (at PIMRC 2014 and WiOpt 2014) and the second model is described in an under-review journal article.

Our third major goal was to develop a threat model to specifically model security threats that might impact a heterogeneous wireless network. To this end, a new security methodology was created (MATINE 2.0) and applied to develop a security threat model for heterogeneous wireless networks. This enabled us to anticipate the security issues for these types of systems, despite their existence only as early-stage research concepts. On the basis of this analysis, we perceived the need for a cellular operator to scrutinize the security of a WLAN network before offloading users, and a tool (SCOUT) was created to allow for such an assessment. 

The research results of this project have broad impacts through their immediate applicability to real networks and their quantification of the benefits of collaboration.
